Sawaddee ka welcome to the final part of my grilled steak 
series on hot side kitchen so in the first part we

grilled a nice piece of steak and in this part 
we're going to serve it in a way that's called

Seua rong hai or The Crying Tiger now that's basically 
the steak slice and served with a dip Cottenham

didn't tell there's many reasons many stories 
behind why it's called The Crying tiger but the

one that I think is the most probable is the tiger 
refers to the crosshatch grill mark of a grilled

steak and The Crying refers to the fact that the 
steak is not cooked all the way so it still has

a little bit of juice running out as the tears of 
the tiger but who knows what the real story is so

I've got the steak resting here since it just came 
off the grill meanwhile we're going to make the

dipping sauce called Nam dipped out which actually 
works with all sorts of real barbecued meats so

I've got here about a tablespoon and a half of 
thinly sliced shallots okay just like that and

to this I'm going to add a tablespoon and a half 
of fish sauce our salty component and then we're

going to go in with one tablespoon of lime juice 
and then I'm going to add another source of acid

tamarind juice I'm using the one that's pre-made 
today and tamarind juice just adds a little bit

of a body to the to the dipping sauce it also 
has a little bit of a well-rounded acidity that

balances the lime very well all that and then I've 
got about a tablespoon and a half of chopped palm

sugar and I this one I actually finally graded 
it because it will dissolve quickly that way

normally I do a a palm sugar syrup which you may 
see me used in other recipes but you can also just

grade it finally in order to solve faster give 
that a quick stir now our spicy source of spicy

some chili flakes as much as useful as you'd 
like okay and then some herbs I've got here

roughly chopped cilantro and green onions about 
a couple tablespoons of each some people like to

add mints to this as well so you can customize 
this to your personal liking and then our final

ingredient our toasted rice powder now I made I 
use this before in the num lock recipe and also

in my lab recipe it's basically just toasted rice 
has been ground up but if you want to know how

that's made I have a separate tutorial just how 
to make toasted rice powder and it'll add a nice

toasty aroma to basically anything you add too 
but it's a particularly nice when something is

very acidic because the nuttiness of this will 
balance it out so about two teaspoons of that

give it a nice stir you don't want to add the 
toasted rice powder too early you want to add

it closer to the time that it's served because 
otherwise it'll start to soak up the liquid and

swell up and it won't be nice anymore to be kind 
of gooey okay so that's our dipping sauce that

our numb team Dell and again that's great with 
them barbeque chicken all sorts of things next

is our steak I've grilled this this is a flank 
steak you want to slice it thinly and I throw

this medium you want it to be pink in the middle 
so that it's not too chewy traditionally they use

the brisket for this which is really chewy you 
want to slice the beef against the direction

of the grain because the shorter the fiber the 
more tender than it is and it's not always going

to run long weighs the grain sometimes runs the 
short way so you have to pay attention it's not

very intuitive sometimes especially for skirt 
steak all right so we're going to take this

and put it on here and always for a nice 
presentation you wanted to shingle it a

little bit so you can see the pink Ness of the 
steak up the beef and fan it around the dressing

and this is of course great with sticky rice 
like all things from the Northeast there you go

and that's it that is our sarong hi it's a very 
simple dish but absolutely delicious and that

concludes the series on grilled steak and for full 
recipes are always full written review darling

crustacean visit hot hydrogen calm and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious tiny
